htmlEmbed:
Vermont State University president recommends cutting 10 degree programs and up to 33 faculty positions - VTDiggerPeter D'Auria10/3/2023

Interim President Mike Smith’s recommendations — which include cutting degrees in forestry, music and school psychology — come after a task force spent several months gathering data and information on the university’s academic programs.

Read

	<span class="cat-links"><span class="screen-reader-text">Posted in</span><a href="https://vtdigger.org/category/education/" rel="category tag">Education</a></span>			<h1 class="entry-title entry-title--with-subtitle">
			Vermont State University president recommends cutting 10 degree programs and up to 33 faculty positions		</h1>
				<div class="newspack-post-subtitle">
			Interim President Mike Smith’s recommendations — which include cutting degrees in forestry, music and school psychology — come after a task force spent several months gathering data and information on the university’s academic programs. 		</div>
	
	<div class="entry-subhead">

<article id="post-558528" class="post-558528 post type-post status-publish format-standard has-post-thumbnail hentry category-education tag-american-federation-of-teachers tag-castleton-university tag-david-bergh tag-linda-olson tag-mike-smith tag-northern-vermont-university tag-vermont-state-university tag-vermont-technical-college entry">
	<div class="entry-content">

		
		<div class="wp-block-image"><figure class="aligncenter size-large"><img decoding="async" width="610" height="406" data-attachment-id="544639" data-permalink="https://vtdigger.org/mike-smith-1-20230524/" data-orig-file="https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524.jpg" data-orig-size="2000,1331" data-comments-opened="0" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"4","credit":"Glenn Russell","camera":"NIKON Z 6","caption":"Mike Smith, interim president of Vermont State University, at the Vermont Technical College campus in Williston on Wednesday, May 24, 2023. Photo by Glenn Russell\/VTDigger","created_timestamp":"1684929268","copyright":"Glenn Russell","focal_length":"70","iso":"1100","shutter_speed":"0.004","title":"mike-smith-1 20230524","orientation":"1"}" data-image-title="mike-smith-1 20230524" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="<p>Mike Smith, interim president of Vermont State University, at the Vermont Technical College campus in Williston on Wednesday, May 24, 2023. Photo by Glenn Russell/VTDigger</p>
" data-medium-file="https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524-300x200.jpg" data-large-file="https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524-610x406.jpg" tabindex="0" role="button" src="https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524-610x406.jpg" alt="a man sitting at a table in front of a laptop computer." class="wp-image-544639" srcset="https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524-610x406.jpg 610w, https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524-300x200.jpg 300w, https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524-125x83.jpg 125w, https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524-768x511.jpg 768w, https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524-1536x1022.jpg 1536w, https://vtdigger.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/05/mike-smith-1-20230524.jpg 2000w" sizes="(max-width: 610px) 100vw, 610px" /><figcaption class="wp-element-caption">Mike Smith, interim president of Vermont State University, at the Vermont Technical College campus in Williston in May. Photo by Glenn Russell/VTDigger</figcaption></figure></div><p>Vermont State University should end 10 degree programs, including agriculture, music and school psychology, and lose around 20-33 faculty positions, Interim President Mike Smith said in a <a href="https://transformation.vsc.edu/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/Optimization-Report-Recommendations_10223_SENT.pdf">draft report</a> issued Oct. 2. </p><p>Smith’s report also recommends consolidating another 13 degree programs and moving 11 among the university’s multiple campuses. None of the recommendations, if implemented, would affect current students in those programs, according to VTSU leadership. The changes would begin in the fall of 2024. </p><p>The school administration is soliciting feedback on the recommendations until Oct. 27, according to the preliminary report, a copy of which was obtained by VTDigger. University leadership will make final decisions by Oct. 31. </p><p>“None of this is easy, and I recognize that impacted faculty will have a period of transition ahead of them,” Smith wrote in the report, adding, “What we are doing with these recommendations is confronting our pressures head on — not running from them — and forging a path to address each and every one of them either through steps to obtain fiscal sustainability, strategic plan for admissions, or a student success model to keep students engaged in academic life.”</p><p>Smith did not immediately respond to calls and texts Monday night. The report is expected to be made public Tuesday morning. </p><aside class="scaip scaip-1    "><style>@media ( min-width: 300px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-1{min-height: 100px;}}@media ( min-width: 728px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-1{min-height: 90px;}}</style>		<div class='newspack_global_ad scaip-1 fixed-height'>
						<!-- /6614979/newspack-in-article-1-6467d25a98075 --><div id='div-gpt-ad-da45e23ca8-0'></div>		</div>
		</aside><p>In the document, Smith recommends discontinuing degrees in agriculture; forestry; landscape contracting; an applied business degree completion program; computer engineering technology; music; photography; performance, arts, and technology; climate change science; and school psychology.</p><p>Ending those programs would not necessarily mean that instruction in those subjects would cease entirely. For example, the report notes that VTSU’s recently created Center for Agriculture and Food Entrepreneurship is working to “identify opportunities for a newly designed Agriculture program that is sustainable and meets the needs of Vermont’s workforce.”</p><p>And while the report recommends ending the degree in climate change science, it also suggests promoting a climate change concentration within an atmospheric sciences degree.</p><p>The programs that Smith recommended cutting currently enroll 77 students, he said, roughly 2% of the university’s student body. All told, the cuts and consolidations proposed in the report would eliminate between 20 to 33 full-time faculty positions — between 10% and 15% of the university’s total of 207.</p><aside class="scaip scaip-2    "><style>@media ( min-width: 300px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-2{min-height: 100px;}}@media ( min-width: 728px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-2{min-height: 90px;}}</style>		<div class='newspack_global_ad scaip-2 fixed-height'>
						<!-- /6614979/newspack-in-article-2-6467d25ad49b2 --><div id='div-gpt-ad-39b7f66083-0'></div>		</div>
		</aside><p>Vermont State University is planning to release details about a buyout program for faculty “in the coming days,” the report states. “If there is sufficient uptake in the buyout program, layoffs may not be necessary.”</p><p>The university was formed this summer <a href="https://vtdigger.org/2023/06/27/after-a-rocky-few-years-vermont-state-university-tries-to-find-its-footing/">through the merger</a> of three public institutions: Castleton University, Northern Vermont University and Vermont Technical College. The merger was intended to put the three on a pathway to financial stability. </p><p>Monday’s report — an initiative that administrators dubbed <a href="https://vtdigger.org/2023/09/20/vermont-state-university-could-consolidate-cut-academic-programs-in-optimization-process/">“Optimization 2.0”</a> — appears to be the next phase of that consolidation. According to Smith, VTSU offers too many academic programs — 99 in total — while some have too few students enrolled. </p><p>That situation, he said, is financially untenable. VTSU ended the most recent fiscal year with a $22 million deficit, and the university “must realize efficiencies now that we are unified,” the report reads.</p><aside class="scaip scaip-3    "><style>@media ( min-width: 300px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-3{min-height: 100px;}}@media ( min-width: 728px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-3{min-height: 90px;}}</style>		<div class='newspack_global_ad scaip-3 fixed-height'>
						<!-- /6614979/newspack-in-article-3-6467d25b43131 --><div id='div-gpt-ad-ad0c38f3ad-0'></div>		</div>
		</aside><p>Smith’s term ends Nov. 1, at which point he will be succeeded by the <a href="https://vtdigger.org/2023/09/22/david-bergh-to-take-over-as-vermont-state-university-interim-president/">recently hired</a> interim president David Bergh, who is expected to run the university for roughly 18 months.</p><p>Monday’s report identifies 13 programs that should be consolidated with others, many of which appear to be already similar. </p><p>It proposes merging a program in architectural & building engineering technology with a program in architectural engineering technology, for example. </p><p>Among other consolidations, the report recommends combining musical theater and theater arts programs, as well as merging a degree in creative writing with one in literature and writing. And it proposes folding a degree in “Health Promotion” into a health science degree or discontinuing it. </p><aside class="scaip scaip-4    "><style>@media ( min-width: 300px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-4{min-height: 100px;}}@media ( min-width: 728px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-4{min-height: 90px;}}</style>		<div class='newspack_global_ad scaip-4 fixed-height'>
						<!-- /6614979/newspack-in-article-4-eva7ycsulyv6h --><div id='div-gpt-ad-3ab184febc-0'></div>		</div>
		</aside><p>Another 11 programs should shift their location from one of the university’s campuses to another, according to the report.</p><p>Last month, in response to complaints from faculty and staff that VTSU employs too many administrators, Smith vowed to examine the institution’s administrative positions and their effect on the budget. In Monday’s report, he reiterated that promise.</p><p>“Please know that I strongly agree that administrative costs of the university must be optimized and reduced as well,” Smith wrote. “With this first set of recommendations out the door I will now turn my attention to administrative costs, releasing a recommendation before my departure at the end of the month.”</p><p>Linda Olson, a sociology professor who represents VTSU faculty for the American Federation of Teachers, said that there were still many unanswered questions about the report. </p><aside class="scaip scaip-5    "><style>@media ( min-width: 300px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-5{min-height: 100px;}}@media ( min-width: 728px ){.newspack_global_ad.scaip-5{min-height: 90px;}}</style>		<div class='newspack_global_ad scaip-5 fixed-height'>
						<!-- /6614979/newspack-in-article-5-6mclxeoxpozzv --><div id='div-gpt-ad-10d601f4df-0'></div>		</div>
		</aside><p>“I think that there needs to be a lot of explanation still about why the proposal is making the recommendations that it is,” she said. “And also, more importantly, what data they’re basing it on.”</p><aside>			<div
								class="newspack-popup-container newspack-popup hidden  newspack-inline-popup  newspack-lightbox-no-border   "
				role="button"
				tabindex="0"
				style="background-color:#EEEEEE;color:#000"
				id="id_585079"
				data-segments=""

readabilityObject.title: Vermont State University president recommends cutting 10 degree programs and up to 33 faculty positions
readabilityObject.content:
Vermont State University should end 10 degree programs, including agriculture, music and school psychology, and lose around 20-33 faculty positions, Interim President Mike Smith said in a draft report issued Oct. 2. 

Smith’s report also recommends consolidating another 13 degree programs and moving 11 among the university’s multiple campuses. None of the recommendations, if implemented, would affect current students in those programs, according to VTSU leadership. The changes would begin in the fall of 2024. 

The school administration is soliciting feedback on the recommendations until Oct. 27, according to the preliminary report, a copy of which was obtained by VTDigger. University leadership will make final decisions by Oct. 31. 

“None of this is easy, and I recognize that impacted faculty will have a period of transition ahead of them,” Smith wrote in the report, adding, “What we are doing with these recommendations is confronting our pressures head on — not running from them — and forging a path to address each and every one of them either through steps to obtain fiscal sustainability, strategic plan for admissions, or a student success model to keep students engaged in academic life.”

Smith did not immediately respond to calls and texts Monday night. The report is expected to be made public Tuesday morning. 

In the document, Smith recommends discontinuing degrees in agriculture; forestry; landscape contracting; an applied business degree completion program; computer engineering technology; music; photography; performance, arts, and technology; climate change science; and school psychology.

Ending those programs would not necessarily mean that instruction in those subjects would cease entirely. For example, the report notes that VTSU’s recently created Center for Agriculture and Food Entrepreneurship is working to “identify opportunities for a newly designed Agriculture program that is sustainable and meets the needs of Vermont’s workforce.”

And while the report recommends ending the degree in climate change science, it also suggests promoting a climate change concentration within an atmospheric sciences degree.

The programs that Smith recommended cutting currently enroll 77 students, he said, roughly 2% of the university’s student body. All told, the cuts and consolidations proposed in the report would eliminate between 20 to 33 full-time faculty positions — between 10% and 15% of the university’s total of 207.

Vermont State University is planning to release details about a buyout program for faculty “in the coming days,” the report states. “If there is sufficient uptake in the buyout program, layoffs may not be necessary.”

The university was formed this summer through the merger of three public institutions: Castleton University, Northern Vermont University and Vermont Technical College. The merger was intended to put the three on a pathway to financial stability. 

Monday’s report — an initiative that administrators dubbed “Optimization 2.0” — appears to be the next phase of that consolidation. According to Smith, VTSU offers too many academic programs — 99 in total — while some have too few students enrolled. 

That situation, he said, is financially untenable. VTSU ended the most recent fiscal year with a $22 million deficit, and the university “must realize efficiencies now that we are unified,” the report reads.

Smith’s term ends Nov. 1, at which point he will be succeeded by the recently hired interim president David Bergh, who is expected to run the university for roughly 18 months.

Monday’s report identifies 13 programs that should be consolidated with others, many of which appear to be already similar. 

It proposes merging a program in architectural & building engineering technology with a program in architectural engineering technology, for example. 

Among other consolidations, the report recommends combining musical theater and theater arts programs, as well as merging a degree in creative writing with one in literature and writing. And it proposes folding a degree in “Health Promotion” into a health science degree or discontinuing it. 

Another 11 programs should shift their location from one of the university’s campuses to another, according to the report.

Last month, in response to complaints from faculty and staff that VTSU employs too many administrators, Smith vowed to examine the institution’s administrative positions and their effect on the budget. In Monday’s report, he reiterated that promise.

“Please know that I strongly agree that administrative costs of the university must be optimized and reduced as well,” Smith wrote. “With this first set of recommendations out the door I will now turn my attention to administrative costs, releasing a recommendation before my departure at the end of the month.”

Linda Olson, a sociology professor who represents VTSU faculty for the American Federation of Teachers, said that there were still many unanswered questions about the report. 

“I think that there needs to be a lot of explanation still about why the proposal is making the recommendations that it is,” she said. “And also, more importantly, what data they’re basing it on.”

readabilityObject.excerpt: Interim President Mike Smith’s recommendations — which include cutting degrees in forestry, music and school psychology — come after a task force spent several months gathering data and information on the university’s academic programs.
